destination.label: Zurich
destination.title: A dynamic city with the charm of a provincial town

content.intro:
Though it is the financial nerve centre of Switzerland, it would be unfortunate to see Zurich only in this light. Yes, the city hosts many banks and corporate headquarters, but it also has much to offer visitors, no matter their budgets.

Built around the Limmat River and the famous Lake Zurich, and crowned by Alpine peaks, this city's romantic charm is undeniably seductive. In summer, Zurich's citizens bask in a supremely peaceful ambience; you and your family should follow their lead. In winter, Zurich's 6,000-square-metre ice-skating rink, the largest in Europe, becomes the main attraction. Exploring the city is best done by bicycle: the municipality provides bikes for adults and children, even electric ones, for free, hardly a negligible detail in a city often ranked among the most expensive in the world.

The old part of town is pedestrian only. Strolling through the many alleys is a pleasure for the eyes: flowering balconies, pretty cafés, and churches, and the many small squares with drinking fountains, of which there are more than 1,200, are just some of the elements that give Zurich's Old Town (Altstadt) its authentic village charm.

If you prefer modern, head to Zurich West, a centre of alternative culture reminiscent of the effervescence of Berlin, filled with trendy spots in refurbished warehouses.

In 2015, The Economist named Zurich the tenth best city to live in in the world, and the second, after Vienna, in Europe. Whether this is due to its manageable size, outstanding setting, or diversity of atmospheres, it is clear that Zurich deserves the high ranking.

content.title: Motel One: Zurich, lake and chocolate

introduction.small: In Zurich's former main post office, Motel One is a trendy hotel with a singular universe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Motel One: Zurich, lake and chocolate

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Zurich's 2nd district stands a rectangular building showcasing a typical early-20th century style of architecture. It is the city's former main post office, now listed as a national heritage monument. Since Motel One took up residence, 394 rooms have replaced the administrative office space.
The hotel was entirely conceived as a tribute to Switzerland, and most especially Lake Zurich and… chocolate. Its original design is revealed in the bedrooms, with turquoise colours reminding customers of the water element, and browns for the cocoa product. The bar is also draped with the colours of Switzerland's speciality, with milk chocolate or caramel walls. The ceiling above the counter is adorned with what looks like gilded aluminium, the kind that is used to wrap up chocolate bars. Your Swiss stay promises to be a pure delight!

Motel One
Stockerstrasse 61
8002 Zurich

+41 (0)44 226 77 00

www.motel-one.com/en/hotels/zurich

Rooms: from 171 CHF

content.title: Josef marks the end of the main course

introduction.small: In Zurich's west district, Josef is a restaurant that brings about a revolution in the art of serving meals by combining them at once.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Josef marks the end of the main course

paragraphs.text:
When passing Josef's threshold, you have to forget about the holy starter-main-dessert trinity. The concept of this Zurich restaurant is halfway between a classic establishment and a tapas/mezze bar. The menu offers dishes inspired by the essentials of Swizz gastronomy with a modern twist, all presented in reduced servings: you will therefore have a choice of a four, five and even six-course meal. Plates then rapidly cover wooden tables, stuck together under a pearly and colourful ceiling, watched over by large 1970s black & white pictures.
Create your own combination of dishes or, if you feel like it, try all the flavours on the menu: Onsen egg and leak mash with mushrooms, pistachios and truffle oil, pork belly confit, served with pumpkin mash and string beans, or a roasted char fillet with a braised hot pepper salad and smoked potato cream… Not mentioning the delectable chocolate fondant for a sweet note. Trying everything at once has never been so simple!

Josef
Gasometerstrasse 24
8005 Zurich

+41 44 271 65 95

www.josef.ch ﻿

Menu: around 52 CHF

content.title: The Widder Hotel, the right balance between old and modern

introduction.small: In the centre of Zurich, nine medieval houses have been renovated to become a five-star hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Widder Hotel, the right balance between old and modern

paragraphs.text:
The Widder Hotel offers a perfect combination of medieval architecture and contemporary design. Nine old 12th-century homes have been renovated to become luxury hotel rooms. Interconnected by a system of bridges, these different homes now make up 49 rooms and suites. Each one, unique, retains its medieval appearance with exposed beams, stone walls and original tiles, while modernised by contemporary furniture. Some suites offer access to a rooftop terrace, boasting a 360° view over all of Zurich.

The Widder Hotel has five restaurants and bars. In the summer, have a seat at Al Fresco for a barbecue on the charming terrace, adorned with hydrangeas and surrounded by ivy-covered walls. Enjoy the shrimp or grilled beef before finishing with a seasonal fruit tart for a sweet touch.

The Widder Hotel
Rennweg 7
8001 Zurich

+41 (0)44 224 25 26

www.widderhotel.com

Rooms: from 620 CHF

content.title: The Viadukt district, Zurich's trendy landmark

introduction.small: During a trip to the Swiss economic capital, make sure to visit this former industrial district undergoing a complete renovation. One of the most dynamic places in the city!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Viadukt district, Zurich's trendy landmark

paragraphs.text:
Head to the west of Zurich to discover the historic Viadukt district, now known as the trendiest place in the city. Formerly devoted to manufacturing and the metalworking industry, the sector – which took advantage of being close to the train station and Limmat River – today gives free rein to art, culture, design and architecture through 60 some shops. A true paradise for shopaholics!

This new urban spot, which stretches over 500 metres long, is also home to the city's very first indoor market, where delicatessens, trendy cafes, nightclubs, fashion shops and art galleries mingle. You will undoubtedly fall for the atypical architecture of the place. All around, rough stone walls remain exposed – even inside the shops –, which accentuates the unique atmosphere and irresistible charm of this new arts district. There is everything to wander, do your shopping, have fun, eat at the restaurant or have a drink with friends.

Markthalle im Viadukt
8005 Zurich

+41 44 412 83 93

www.im-viadukt.ch/en/home/?lang=set

content.title: Zurich West: the city's new trendy area

introduction.small: The Zurich West district is the true symbol of Zurich's cultural revival.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zurich West: the city's new trendy area

paragraphs.text: A former industrial quarter, Zurich West has become the city's hippest neighbourhood, where the young and trendy come to shop, eat, and drink in the trendy establishments that have taken over the old factories and warehouses. This area testifies eloquently to the dynamism and creativity of Zurich. Two spots are particularly noteworthy. Start at the Puls 5 mall, whose modern lines hide the infrastructure of an old foundry, and continue to Freitag, a fashion institution in Zurich and around the world. Located in a tower of old containers, Freitag sells wallets, bags, and other accessories made from materials like old truck tarpaulins and seat belts. It is emblematic of this district where, consistently, the resources of the past are reinvented creatively and intelligently.

content.title: Zurich's botanical garden: a little paradise in the city

introduction.small: Gorgeous scenery, fresh air, and tranquillity are the main attractions at Zurich's green lung.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zurich's botanical garden: a little paradise in the city

paragraphs.text:
Zurich, with its lake and the nearby Alps, is not, properly speaking, a very polluted city, but a stroll through the University of Zurich's botanical garden is still a welcome breath of fresh air. The visual and olfactory attractions are stunning, especially in the large greenhouses, which house more than one-and-a-half million plants. Each of the greenhouses was designed to recreate the environment of three kinds of plants: savannah, tropical, and subtropical. Whatever the season, but especially, of course, during the summer, the garden deserves its due. After visiting the different sections (Mediterranean, Alpine, etc.), settle in for a picnic around the pond. Though free, the park is generally overlooked by tourists, which makes it even more attractive.


Botanical Garden of the University of Zurich

Zollikerstrasse 107

8008 Zurich


+41 (0)44 634 84 61


www.bg.uzh.ch/index_en.html

content.title: Lake Zurich: the essential Zurich experience

introduction.small: For a day with family or friends, Lake Zurich is the ideal place to chill out.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake Zurich: the essential Zurich experience

paragraphs.text:
Without its lake Zurich would not be Zurich.

In winter, it provides the misty atmosphere peculiar to the city. But with the return of warm weather you can really enjoy the life that develops around its shores. Water activities like canoeing, windsurfing, and pedal boating abound. If you don't want to strain yourself too much, discover the lake via the boat that departs from Bürkliplatz, at the end of Bahnhofstrasse. Swimming is free all around the lake.

Some spots, like Enge Wiese, are especially popular with locals. For lunch, you are spoiled for choice: you can picnic, eat in one of the many beach bars or terraces, or use the barbecue grills available near the Chinese Garden. And this Chinese Garden, with its pagodas and small bridges from the Chinese city of Kunming, is worth the trip alone.

content.title: Fraumünster Church: a church-museum in the centre of Zurich

introduction.small: Fraumünster Church, with its stained-glass windows by Giacometti and Chagall, is the pride of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fraumünster Church: a church-museum in the centre of Zurich

paragraphs.text:
The exterior of Fraumünster Church is sober and elegant, with its large clock and golden-green arrow pointing up at the clouds.
The interior may go unnoticed, but it contains some artistic jewels, including the dazzling stained-glass window by Alberto Giacometti in the north transept, created in 1940, and Marc Chagall's five windows in the abbey's choir, created in 1970. The church, both Romanesque and Gothic, was part of an abbey for women founded in the year 853. Unfortunately, the cloister and abbey buildings were destroyed in the 19th century.
Don't miss the impressive organ, consisting of no fewer than 5,793 pipes, making it the largest in the canton of Zurich.

Fraümunster Church
Münsterhof 2
8001 Zurich

+41 (0)44 221 20 63

www.fraumuenster.ch

content.title: Cabaret Voltaire: in the footsteps of Dada

introduction.small: In this unique and historic place, discover the birthplace of Dadaism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cabaret Voltaire: in the footsteps of Dada

paragraphs.text:
At Spiegelgasse 1, in the Old Town, where Lenin spent a year in exile, is the Cabaret Voltaire. In 1916, it became the birthplace of Dadaism, an intellectual, artistic, and literary movement that, in response to the Great War, questioned norms and conventions.

Today, the place still has an atmosphere of challenge and disintegration, as evidenced by the decorations, which include a bust of Voltaire and disco balls. The mostly young audience comes to read in peace in the afternoon. In the evening, absinthe-fuelled debates, film screenings, literary events and even stand-up comedy take over the venue.

The Cabaret Voltaire is more than a bar: with a library, a permanent Dada exhibition, and a shop selling local artwork, it is a full-blown cultural centre.

Cabaret Voltaire
Spiegelgasse 1
8001 Zurich

+44 (0)43 268 57 20

www.cabaretvoltaire.ch

content.title: Bahnhofstrasse: the most expensive street in Europe

introduction.small: Whether for window-shopping or a full-out spree, Bahnhofstrasse is the place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bahnhofstrasse: the most expensive street in Europe

paragraphs.text:
Zurich's main shopping street, Bahnhofstrasse, offers more than a kilometre's worth of ways to lighten your wallet. Ready-to-wear shops gradually give way to major luxury brands on this long pedestrian street, which starts at the station and ends at the edge of the lake.
To regain your strength, stop in at the Confiserie Sprüngli for a coffee and a chance to sample their specialities: luxemburgerli (macaroons) and delicious truffles. Some prefer the rival chocolatier, Läderach, at number 106. Their bars, sold by weight, in original and subtle flavours (for example the pink pepper and strawberry), are exceptionally delicious.
At Christmas, Bahnhofstrasse is adorned with thousands of lights, giving the street an almost magical appearance.

Bahnhofstrasse
8001 Zurich

content.title: Design Hotel Plattenhof: just like home

introduction.small: Sheltered from the bustle of the city, the Plattenhof is a charming hotel where everything is Zen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Design Hotel Plattenhof: just like home

paragraphs.text:
There is first of all the classic but elegant four-storey building in which you enter. A glass is immediately proffered, giving you the presentiment that your stay at the Design Hotel Plattenhof will unfold in the best of ways.

Thereafter, you can be sure that this impression will be confirmed: the staff, always attentive, will do everything to make you feel at home. The 37 rooms are medium in size (15 to 23 square metres), but the intimate atmosphere is ever so cosy! Blonde wood floors and large windows give the sand-coloured rooms a particular brightness, and the large Japanese beds will make you forget the bustle of the city.

The hotel is located in the quiet university district (just steps from the botanical garden), but the centre of Zurich is only ten minutes away by tram.

Design Hotel Plattenhof
Plattenstrasse 26
8032 Zurich

+41 (0)44 251 19 10

www.plattenhof.ch/en/

content.title: Hotel Helvetia: an address of understated elegance

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, the Hotel Helvetia and its restaurant are Zurich institutions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Helvetia: an address of understated elegance

paragraphs.text:
Located 500 metres from the train station, the Hotel Helvetia almost immediately seduces you with its pastel facade, dating from the 19th century.

Consisting of only 35 rooms and two apartments, it is an intimate establishment offering very personalised service. The interior is unpretentious yet elegant. The grey striped wallpaper, the brightness, and the decor give the rooms a certain refinement that is both classic and contemporary.

In fine weather, the rooftop bar is a must; it's the ideal place to enjoy a cocktail with friends while taking in a sunset. Whatever the weather, definitely book a table in the restaurant. The chefs, Marek Sztukowski and Diego von Büren cleverly mix Swiss tradition and Mediterranean influences, using only the freshest products found in local markets.

Hotel Helvetia
Stauffacherquai 1
8004 Zurich

+41 (0)44 297 99 99

www.hotel-helvetia.ch

Rooms: from 189 CHF

content.title: Kunsthaus: Zurich's most important art museum

introduction.small: Rich collections ranging from medieval to contemporary await you at the Kunsthaus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kunsthaus: Zurich's most important art museum

paragraphs.text:
With more than 50 museums, Zurich can lay claim to being an art capital as much as a capital of capitalism. If you were to visit only one museum, make it the Kunsthaus (Museum of Fine Arts), which is among the most famous in Europe.

Its collections, exhibited in bright, airy galleries, include more than 4,000 paintings and sculptures from the Middle Ages to the here and now. Among the masterpieces are those by Flemish painters, such as Rubens, Impressionists like Monet, Manet, Cezanne, and Van Gogh, Nordic expressionists the museum has the largest Edvard Munch collection outside of Norway and modernists like Mondrian, Chagall, and Kandinsky.

An entire room is dedicated to the works of local artist Alberto Giacometti. Plan to spend at least two hours, and keep in mind that admission to the permanent collection is free on Wednesdays.

Kunsthaus
Heimplatz 1
8001 Zurich

+41 (0)44 253 84 84

www.kunsthaus.ch

content.title: Uetliberg: the top of Zurich

introduction.small: Enjoy a big breath of fresh air just minutes from the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Uetliberg: the top of Zurich

paragraphs.text:
Zurich's 20-minute proximity to Uetliberg, the ‘Zurich summit', is a big plus for the city. Easily accessible from the central train station aboard the Uetliberg Bahn or by bus, the mountain overlooks the city and lake and offers a breath-taking view of the snow-capped Alps.
If you want an even more spectacular view and you're not faint of heart go to the top of the 72-metre observation tower near the Hotel Uto Kulm. This is a popular hiking and picnicking area there are tables all around.
The 821-metre climb to Uetliberg's summit will tempt the athletic traveller, who can also do it on mountain bike. In winter, the roads become trails for cross-country skiing and sledding.

Uetliberg
8143 Zurich

content.title: Schipfe: the charms of the Old Town

introduction.small: The residential district of Schipfe is the ideal place in Zurich for a stroll.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Schipfe: the charms of the Old Town

paragraphs.text:
Located on the left bank of the Limmat, this former shipyard area has become a peaceful residential district, still relatively unknown to tourists. Part of the Old Town (Altstadt), it has no shortage of cobbled and colourful streets, charming shops, artisan's studios, and inexpensive restaurants.

Head to Lindenhof hill and its square lined with 90 linden trees, which has a beautiful view of the River Limmat and the Old Town. As the only green area in the district, it is very popular with locals of all ages.

You may come across lovers, kids enjoying the swings and sandbox, and old men playing a game of petanque or giant chess. The stunning views make this well worth the short climb.

content.title: Restaurant Rosso: the best Italian food in Zurich

introduction.small: In an abandoned factory, taste some of the finest pizzas north of Naples.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Restaurant Rosso: the best Italian food in Zurich

paragraphs.text:
Like most Zurich West district buildings, Rosso looks like nothing more than an old abandoned factory. But don't be fooled! Just steps from the Freitag Tower, Rosso is considered the best Italian restaurant in Zurich.
Although quite poorly indicated, the address is popular among locals and young people. In an unaltered industrial setting, the kitchen turns out great fish dishes, homemade pasta, and, especially, pizzas – with thin and crispy crusts topped with fresh ingredients.
Expect no dinner formalities: for instance, water is free and you can fill your pitcher as many times as you feel like. As for the wine list, it is mainly Italian, with some nice local choices too.

Restaurant Rosso
Geroldstrasse 31
8005 Zurich

+41 (0)43 818 22 54

www.restaurant-rosso.ch

Menu: around 28 CHF

content.title: Helvti Diner: a genuine American diner

introduction.small: Helvti Diner has the best burgers in Zurich.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Helvti Diner: a genuine American diner

paragraphs.text:
Go through the door of Helvti Diner and you'll be forgiven if you feel you've landed on America's mythical Route 66! Open since 2011, this purple and red diner is always packed.

The star item is the burger, which you concoct yourself by choosing the size of the patty, the beef Swiss, Alpine, Angus, or Kobe the type of cheese, and all the fixings. If you still have an appetite unlikely, because the burgers are pretty impressive go for a milkshake, which comes with a good dose of whipped cream, and a cherry on top.

If you're overwhelmed by a craving for a really good burger, this is definitely the place to go.

Helvti Diner
Kasernenstrasse 2
8004 Zurich

+41 (0)43 322 04 24

www.helvti-diner.ch

Menu: from 33 CHF

content.title: The Dolder Grand: more than a hotel, an art gallery

introduction.small: Immerse your senses in the Dolder Grand, with its superb views over Zurich, huge spa, and masterpiece paintings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dolder Grand: more than a hotel, an art gallery

paragraphs.text:
Located on the heights of Zurich, The Dolder Grand is an impressive and alluring palace. The historic building dates from 1899 and overlooks Zurich and Lake Zurich, with stunning views of the Alps and the surrounding forest.

Renovated in 2008 by renowned British architect Norman Foster, it consists of 175 rooms and suites, all very bright. Here everything is done to ensure an exceptional stay: the staff is very attentive, especially in the gourmet restaurant (two Michelin stars) and the impressive 4,000-square-metres spa with panoramic pool. The decor is magical. In the spacious lounge bar, where guests enjoy amazing cocktails that use tea (!) as a base, the chandeliers seem to float in the air.

Art lovers will also appreciate the many masterpieces more than 100 scattered throughout the hotel by such luminaries as Dalí, Pissaro, Warhol, Keith Haring, and Anish Kapoor.

The Dolder Grand
Kurhausstrasse 65
8032 Zurich

+41 (0)44 456 60 00

www.thedoldergrand.com

Rooms: from 1,050 CHF

content.title: B2 Boutique Hotel: a relaxing stay in a former brewery

introduction.small: Treat yourself to an exceptional stay of relaxation and comfort in a unique setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: B2 Boutique Hotel: a relaxing stay in a former brewery

paragraphs.text:
At the B2 Boutique Hotel + Spa Zurich, a former brewery now artfully transformed into a hotel, meals are taken in an impressive library that holds 33,000 books, and are lit by huge chandeliers made of green beer bottles.

In the underground spa, you bathe in old wooden vats under huge stone arches. Particular attention is given to detail: the staff is very attentive, the rooms contain sleek coffee machines, and the decor is bright and tastefully minimal.

The rooftop pool, which offers panoramic views of Zurich,will leave a lasting impression, especially if you go as the sun sets over the city's steeples.

B2 Boutique Hotel + Spa
Brandschenkestrasse 152
8002 Zurich

+41 (0)44 567 67 67

www.b2boutiquehotels.com

content.title: Les Halles: French retro charm

introduction.small: A new trendy address in Zurich, serving classic French bistro fare.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Halles: French retro charm

paragraphs.text:
Located in the fashionable Zurich West district, Les Halles offers unpretentious dishes in a warm and relaxed atmosphere.

The decor is 1960s French garage, with rusty bicycles, faded Peugeot billboards, and large wooden tables. The food is classic bistro: mussels with cream, traditional steak tartar, soup of the day, or a warm goat cheese salad.The products used are mostly organic, and the prices, by Zurich standards, are reasonable.

After your meal, play a game of table football and, like many locals, check out the adjoining wine shop, which has a great selection of wines from small producers, and stays open till 11:00 p.m., something quite rare in Zurich.

Les Halles
Pfingstweidstrasse 6
8005 Zurich

+41 (0)44 273 11 25

www.les-halles.ch

Menu: around 55 CHF

content.title: Hiltl: a vegetarian institution since 1898

introduction.small: Experience a gourmet vegetarian restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hiltl: a vegetarian institution since 1898

paragraphs.text:
To those who claim that vegetarianism is a recent mode and that a vegetarian meal means eating bland food, bring them to Hiltl. Even the fiercest carnivores fall under the charm of the oldest vegetarian restaurant in Europe, opened in 1898.

In a contemporary decor with large picture windows, two choices are available: the menu or the huge buffet. If you order from the menu, try the famous tartar, which, though meatless, surprisingly approximates the taste of a true steak tartar. The buffet is fabulous, too.

The colour and freshness of the products, the fast and professional service, and the reinterpretations of classic Italian, Indian, Chinese, and Swiss dishes including a fabulous rösti, the speciality potato pancake are all delicious.

Hiltl
Sihlstrasse 28
8001 Zurich

+41 (0)44 227 70 00

www.hiltl.ch/en/

Menu: around 16 CHF

content.title: Maison Blunt: a flavourful journey to the Middle East

introduction.small: Colourful cuisine and a lovely setting await you at Maison Blunt.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maison Blunt: a flavourful journey to the Middle East

paragraphs.text:
A very popular address among Zurichers, the Maison Blunt serves excellent Moroccan and Lebanese cuisine in a beautiful Middle Eastern setting that makes you want to jump on the Orient Express.

Depending on what time you come, you'll be installed either in the restaurant area or in the tearoom (the restaurant is open for lunch and dinner). There are fresh flowers on the tables and beautiful mosaics everywhere. While you wait, a basket arrives filled with a variety of Middle Eastern bread.

Order a couscous or a tagine, or, if you are a vegetarian, the mezze. Whatever your choice, it will be colourful and aromatic. The restaurant is richly coloured, and the tearoom even more so; the mosaics, low tables, and armchairs covered with kilim are enchanting. Can you imagine a better place to share a mint tea with friends?

Maison Blunt
Gasometerstrasse 5
8005 Zurich

+41 (0)43 211 00 33

www.maison-blunt.ch

Menu: from 28 CHF

content.title: 25Hours Zurich West: mischievous and playful charm

introduction.small: Discover 25Hours, the hotel that best reflects the creative energy of Zurich West.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 25Hours Zurich West: mischievous and playful charm

paragraphs.text:
This large black building in Zurich's trendiest district contains a Technicolor world!

The hotel was designed by Alfredo Häberli in a playful and mischievous manner, with a myriad of colours and humorous messages everywhere: on a mirror (‘Is the mirror honest with me?') or your pillow (‘Let's spend the night together!'). The attention to detail is impressive and the reception staff charming and friendly.

After a day sightseeing in town, enjoy the rooftop sauna with a magnificent view of the neighbourhood. Another plus: during your stay, the hotel supplies you with a Freitag bag, the must-have accessory for any self-respecting Zuricher.

25Hours Zurich West
Pfingstweidstrasse 102
8005 Zurich

+41 (0)44 577 25 25

www.25hours-hotels.com/en/zurich-west

content.title: Grossmünster: in the footsteps of Charlemagne

introduction.small: Climb to the top of the Charlemagne Tower and enjoy the most beautiful view of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grossmünster: in the footsteps of Charlemagne

paragraphs.text:
Grossmünster Cathedral, with its two binocular towers, is a Zurich icon. Legend has it that the first Carolingian version of the building, which is located in the Old Town, on the right bank of the Limmat, was commissioned by Charlemagne, whose statue you can take a look at in the Romanesque crypt. The present building dates from 1220.
The interior is very simple, but the organ is considered the finest in Switzerland, and the agate windows by Sigmar Polke are definitely worth a look. The cathedral's key asset, however, is the view that awaits you from the top.
Be forewarned, however, that to reach the most beautiful panoramic view of Zurich means climbing the 187 steps of the spiral staircase in the south tower, the Karlsturm (aka the Charlemagne Tower).

Grossmünster
Grossmünsterplatz
8001 Zurich

+41 (0)44 252 59 49

www.grossmuenster.ch/de/

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Zurich
content.introduction: Located in the north-east of Switzerland, Zurich has a temperate climate. The city's weather is affected periodically by the föhn, a warm, dry wind blowing from the south, which spills through Swiss alpine passes and heats up as it descends. On the other hand, when the wind known as the bise blows in from the east, air temperatures can cool significantly. Winters are rather cold and summers can be quite warm.

airports.title: Zurich International Airport
airports.description:
The Zurich International Airport is located in Kloten, about 13 kilometres (8 miles) north of Zurich's city centre.
  • Three terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France)
    • Terminal 3

Getting from the airport to Zurich and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A1L and the A48 motorways.
    • Three parking garages linked to the main airport building are intended especially for shorter stays (P1, P2 and P3; CHF 2 for 15 minutes, CHF 6 for 1 hour and CHF 3 for each additional hour).
    • Drop-off and pick-up areas located near check-in outside terminals 1 and 2 (first five minutes free, CHF 1 per extra minute). Short-term parking facilities located at the arrivals level of terminals 1 and 2 (CHF 10 for 30 minutes, CHF 20 for 1 hour). Several parking facilities are connected to the check-ins (P1, P2 and P3, CHF 8 for 1 day), long-term parking facilities (P60, P16 and P17, about CHF 150 per week).
    • Several car rental companies have counters on Level 1 of the Airport Center.
  • By rail
    • Trains leave for Zurich's main train station (Hauptbahnhof) from the station on Level −2 of the Airport Center every 5-10 minutes during the day. The travel time is about 20 minutes and the fare is CHF 6.80 each way.
  • By tram shuttle
    • Line 10 of the Glattalbahn tram system connects the airport with Zurich's main train station every 7-15 minutes via Glattpark, Zurich-Oerlikon, Milchbuck and Irchel, which can be useful for reaching certain hotels. The trip takes about 30 minutes and the fare is the same as that for the train, CHF 6.80.
  • By bus
    • Buses are located near the airport, behind parking facilities P2 and P3. A one-way ticket costs CHF 10.
  • By shuttle
    • Connecting the main station via Glattpark, Zurich-Oerliko, Milchbuck and Irchel. Shuttles leave every 10 minutes. A one-way ticket costs CHF 25.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the arrivals levels of both terminals. The trip to central Zurich takes about 20 minutes and costs about CHF 70.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +41 (0)43 816 22 11
  • Website: https://www.zurich-airport.com/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Zurich
transportation.description: Zurich has introduced a number of policies designed to limit car traffic in the city. As a result, the simplest ways to get around the city are on foot, or by tram and bus. City planners focus great efforts on making public transport easy and convenient. Along most routes, there is a bus stop or tram station roughly every quarter mile or less. Moreover, an integrated fare system is used for all modes of transport. A single ticket valid for 30 minutes costs CHF 2.70.

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Zurich counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic German phrases that will make your stay in Zurich a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Guten Morgen (morning) / Guten Tag (during the day)
Could you repeat ?: Können Sie bitte wiederholen?
What time is it ?: Wie spät ist es?
How much is (…)?: Wie viel kostet es?
Where can I find (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) finden?
Where can I buy (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) kaufen?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Zurich
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Zurich each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national)
events.description: Easter Monday commemorates the resurrection of Jesus Christ on the third day after the Passion. Many baptisms are celebrated on Easter Weekend and families come together to attend the vigil mass and share a feast on Sunday.

events.title: Third Monday in April: Sechseläuten (Burning of the Böögg, local)
events.description: To usher in spring, Zurich's guilds parade in medieval costumes through the city's streets. Celebrations culminate at 6 p.m. with the ringing of all the city bells and the burning of the Böögg, a huge figure of a snowman prepared with explosives, thus driving out winter.

events.title: August 1: National Day (national)
events.description: Commemorates the founding of the Swiss Confederation on this day in 1291. An evening cruise on Lake Zurich is the best way to see bonfires and fireworks. Other highlights include official ceremonies, concerts and activities for children.

events.title: First week in September: Zurich Film Festival (local)
events.description: This 11-day festival features the work of both established and emerging filmmakers attracts many big names and some 80,000 spectators to its premieres, screenings, galas and red-carpet events at various venues across Zurich.

events.title: Second week in October: Art International Zurich (local)
events.description: This three-day contemporary art fair is held every year at Kongresshaus Zurich, with works for sale by young and emerging artists in the fields of painting, graphics, sculpture and photography.

events.title: Second Friday in November: Swiss story night (national event)
events.description: Set up each year since 1995, this event sheds a light on Swiss oral traditions. All-nighters take place in various libraries, schools and unusual places for public readings of traditional stories.

events.title: December 1-24: Christmas market (Christkindlmarkten - national)
events.description: As the Christmas season draws near, this major event for local crafts takes place on Zurich's main squares. Numerous cabins also offer gastronomical delicacies and Christmas decorations.

events.title: December 31: Neujahrsmarathon Zurich (local)
events.description: This is the only international marathon starting at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve. Headlamps are therefore recommended for all runners, because although the course is marked by signposts, barrier tape and flags, it is not illuminated! Spectacular fireworks are set off as the race begins and along the course.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Switzerland
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need a visa to enter Switzerland. You must be in possession of a national identity card or a passport valid for the proposed duration of your stay. If you wish to remain in Switzerland for more than three months, you will need to apply for a residence permit from the immigration office of the canton in which you plan to stay.

To travel serenely in Zurich and Switzerland, follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs

https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/switzerland/#

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Switzerland, as is also the case in France and Italy, leaving a tip is recommended when the service is especially friendly and attentive. The appropriate amount is anywhere between 5 and 10% of the bill at restaurants or bars.
